column1: Old Havana and its Fortifications,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection

Havana was founded in 1519 by the Spanish. By the 17th century, it had become one of the Caribbean's main centres for ship-building. Although it is today a sprawling metropolis of 2 million inhabitants, its old centre retains an interesting mix of Baroque and neoclassical monuments, and a homogeneous ensemble of private houses with arcades, balconies, wrought-iron gates and internal courtyards.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Talamanca Range-La Amistad Reserves / La Amistad National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Talamanca Range-La Amistad Reserves / La Amistad National Park

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The location of this unique site in Central America, where Quaternary glaciers have left their mark, has allowed the fauna and flora of North and South America to interbreed. Tropical rainforests cover most of the area. Four different Indian tribes inhabit this property, which benefits from close co-operation between Costa Rica and Panama.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Central Zone of the Town of Angra do Heroismo in the Azores,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Central Zone of the Town of Angra do Heroismo in the Azores

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Central Zone of the Town of Angra do Heroismo in the Azores

Situated on one of the islands in the Azores archipelago, this was an obligatory port of call from the 15th century until the advent of the steamship in the 19th century. The 400-year-old San Sebastiï¿½o and San Joï¿½o Baptista fortifications are unique examples of military architecture. Damaged by an earthquake in 1980, Angra is now being restored.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Cultural Landscape and Archaeological Remains of the Bamiyan Valley,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Cultural Landscape and Archaeological Remains of the Bamiyan Valley

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
General view of the Bamiyan Valley

The cultural landscape and archaeological remains of the Bamiyan Valley represent the artistic and religious developments which from the 1st to the 13th centuries characterized ancient Bakhtria, integrating various cultural influences into the Gandhara school of Buddhist art. The area contains numerous Buddhist monastic ensembles and sanctuaries, as well as fortified edifices from the Islamic period. The site is also testimony to the tragic destruction by the Taliban of the two standing Buddha statues, which shook the world in March 2001.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Ancient City of Aleppo,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Located at the crossroads of several trade routes from the 2nd millennium B.C., Aleppo was ruled successively by the Hittites, Assyrians, Arabs, Mongols, Mamelukes and Ottomans. The 13th-century citadel, 12th-century Great Mosque and various 17th-century madrasas, palaces, caravanserais and hammams all form part of the city's cohesive, unique urban fabric, now threatened by overpopulation.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Minaret and Archaeological Remains of Jam,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Minaret and Archaeological Remains of Jam

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Minaret and Archaeological Remains of Jam

The 65m-tall Minaret of Jam is a graceful, soaring structure, dating back to the 12th century. Covered in elaborate brickwork with a blue tile inscription at the top, it is noteworthy for the quality of its architecture and decoration, which represent the culmination of an architectural and artistic tradition in this region. Its impact is heightened by its dramatic setting, a deep river valley between towering mountains in the heart of the Ghur province.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Rila Monastery,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Rila Monastery was founded in the 10th century by St John of Rila, a hermit canonized by the Orthodox Church. His ascetic dwelling and tomb became a holy site and were transformed into a monastic complex which played an important role in the spiritual and social life of medieval Bulgaria. Destroyed by fire at the beginning of the 19th century, the complex was rebuilt between 1834 and 1862. A characteristic example of the Bulgarian Renaissance (18th&ndash
column2: 19th centuries), the monument symbolizes the awareness of a Slavic cultural identity following centuries of occupation.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Ancient City of Nessebar,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Situated on a rocky peninsula on the Black Sea, the more than 3,000-year-old site of Nessebar was originally a Thracian settlement (Menebria). At the beginning of the 6th century BC, the city became a Greek colony. The city&rsquo
column2: s remains, which date mostly from the Hellenistic period, include the acropolis, a temple of Apollo, an agora and a wall from the Thracian fortifications. Among other monuments, the Stara Mitropolia Basilica and the fortress date from the Middle Ages, when this was one of the most important Byzantine towns on the west coast of the Black Sea. Wooden houses built in the 19th century are typical of the Black Sea architecture of the period.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Srebarna Nature Reserve,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The Srebarna Nature Reserve is a freshwater lake adjacent to the Danube and extending over 600 ha. It is the breeding ground of almost 100 species of birds, many of which are rare or endangered. Some 80 other bird species migrate and seek refuge there every winter. Among the most interesting bird species are the Dalmatian pelican, great egret, night heron, purple heron, glossy ibis and white spoonbill.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Ancient City of Bosra,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Bosra, once the capital of the Roman province of Arabia, was an important stopover on the ancient caravan route to Mecca. A magnificent 2nd-century Roman theatre, early Christian ruins and several mosques are found within its great walls.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Pirin National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection

Spread over an area of over 27,000 ha, at an altitude between 1008 and 2914 m in the Pirin Mountains, southwest Bulgaria, the site comprises diverse limestone mountain landscapes with glacial lakes, waterfalls, caves and predominantly coniferous forests. It was added to the World Heritage List in 1983. The extension now covers an area of around 40,000 ha in the Pirin Mountains, and overlaps with the Pirin National Park, except for two areas developed for tourism (skiing). The dominant part of the extension is high mountain territory over 2000m in altitude, and covered mostly by alpine meadows, rocky screes and summits.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column2: National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column3: National Park

column1: One of the largest protected areas in West Africa, this park is characterized by its great plant diversity. Due to the presence of the Comoé
column2: river, it contains plants which are normally only found much farther south, such as shrub savannahs and patches of thick rainforest.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Historic Centre of Avignon: Papal Palace, Episcopal Ensemble and Avignon Bridge,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Historic Centre of Avignon: Papal Palace, Episcopal Ensemble and Avignon Bridge

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

In the 14th century, this city in the South of France was the seat of the papacy. The Palais des Papes, an austere-looking fortress lavishly decorated by Simone Martini and Matteo Giovanetti, dominates the city, the surrounding ramparts and the remains of a 12th-century bridge over the Rhone. Beneath this outstanding example of Gothic architecture, the Petit Palais and the Romanesque Cathedral of Notre-Dame-des-Doms complete an exceptional group of monuments that testify to the leading role played by Avignon in 14th-century Christian Europe.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Place Stanislas, Place de la Carrière and Place d'Alliance in Nancy,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc""><strong>Place Stanislas, Place de la Carri&#xe8
column3: re and Place d&apos

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Nancy, the temporary residence of a king without a kingdom ï¿½ Stanislas Leszczynski, later to become Duke of Lorraine ï¿½ is paradoxically the oldest and most typical example of a modern capital where an enlightened monarch proved to be sensitive to the needs of the public. Built between 1752 and 1756 by a brilliant team led by the architect Hï¿½rï¿½, this was a carefully conceived project that succeeded in creating a capital that not only enhanced the sovereign's prestige but was also functional.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Site of Palmyra,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

An oasis in the Syrian desert, north-east of Damascus, Palmyra contains the monumental ruins of a great city that was one of the most important cultural centres of the ancient world. From the 1st to the 2nd century, the art and architecture of Palmyra, standing at the crossroads of several civilizations, married Graeco-Roman techniques with local traditions and Persian influences.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Abbey Church of Saint-Savin sur Gartempe,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Abbey Church of Saint-Savin sur Gartempe

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

column3: , the Abbey-Church of Saint-Savin contains many beautiful 11th- and 12th-century murals which are still in a remarkable state of preservation.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Red Fort Complex,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Diwan-i-Amm the buit, view of red sand stone colonnades.
The Red Fort Complex was built as the palace fort of Shahjahanabad &ndash
column2: the new capital of the fifth Mughal Emperor of India, Shah Jahan. Named for its massive enclosing walls of red sandstone, it is adjacent to an older fort, the Salimgarh, built by Islam Shah Suri in 1546, with which it forms the Red Fort Complex. The private apartments consist of a row of pavilions connected by a continuous water channel, known as the Nahr-i-Behisht (Stream of Paradise). The Red Fort is considered to represent the zenith of Mughal creativity which, under the Shah Jahan, was brought to a new level of refinement. The planning of the palace is based on Islamic prototypes, but each pavilion reveals architectural elements typical of Mughal building, reflecting a fusion of Persian, Timurid and Hindu traditions The Red Fort&rsquo
column3: s innovative planning and architectural style, including the garden design, strongly influenced later buildings and gardens in Rajasthan, Delhi, Agra and further afield.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Humayun's Tomb, Delhi,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column3: s Tomb, Delhi

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

This tomb, built in 1570, is of particular cultural significance as it was the first garden-tomb on the Indian subcontinent. It inspired several major architectural innovations, culminating in the construction of the Taj Mahal.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Qutb Minar and its Monuments, Delhi,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Qutb Minar and its Monuments, Delhi

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Built in the early 13th century a few kilometres south of Delhi, the red sandstone tower of Qutb Minar is 72.5 m high, tapering from 2.75 m in diameter at its peak to 14.32 m at its base, and alternating angular and rounded flutings. The surrounding archaeological area contains funerary buildings, notably the magnificent Alai-Darwaza Gate, the masterpiece of Indo-Muslim art (built in 1311), and two mosques, including the Quwwatu'l-Islam, the oldest in northern India, built of materials reused from some 20 Brahman temples.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Churches and Convents of Goa,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
The churches and convents of Goa, the former capital of the Portuguese Indies &ndash
column2: particularly the Church of Bom Jesus, which contains the tomb of St Francis-Xavier &ndash
column3: illustrate the evangelization of Asia. These monuments were influential in spreading forms of Manueline, Mannerist and Baroque art in all the countries of Asia where missions were established.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Group of Monuments at Pattadakal,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Pattadakal, in Karnataka, represents the high point of an eclectic art which, in the 7th and 8th centuries under the Chalukya dynasty, achieved a harmonious blend of architectural forms from northern and southern India. An impressive series of nine Hindu temples, as well as a Jain sanctuary, can be seen there. One masterpiece from the group stands out &ndash
column2: the Temple of Virupaksha, built c. 740 by Queen Lokamahadevi to commemorate her husband's victory over the kings from the South.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Nahanni National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Located along the South Nahanni River, one of the most spectacular wild rivers in North America, this park contains deep canyons and huge waterfalls, as well as a unique limestone cave system. The park is also home to animals of the boreal forest, such as wolves, grizzly bears and caribou. Dall's sheep and mountain goats are found in the park's alpine environment.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Khajuraho Group of Monuments,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
One of the temples at the western temple complex in Khajuraho. This one is dedicated to Shiva, with the bull standing guard on the other side of the entrance.
The temples at Khajuraho were built during the Chandella dynasty, which reached its apogee between 950 and 1050. Only about 20 temples remain
column2: they fall into three distinct groups and belong to two different religions &ndash
column3: Hinduism and Jainism. They strike a perfect balance between architecture and sculpture. The Temple of Kandariya is decorated with a profusion of sculptures that are among the greatest masterpieces of Indian art.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Group of Monuments at Hampi,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The austere, grandiose site of Hampi was the last capital of the last great Hindu Kingdom of Vijayanagar. Its fabulously rich princes built Dravidian temples and palaces which won the admiration of travellers between the 14th and 16th centuries. Conquered by the Deccan Muslim confederacy in 1565, the city was pillaged over a period of six months before being abandoned.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Ajanta Caves,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The first Buddhist cave monuments at Ajanta date from the 2nd and 1st centuries B.C. During the Gupta period (5th and 6th centuries A.D.), many more richly decorated caves were added to the original group. The paintings and sculptures of Ajanta, considered masterpieces of Buddhist religious art, have had a considerable artistic influence.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Ellora Caves,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

These 34 monasteries and temples, extending over more than 2 km, were dug side by side in the wall of a high basalt cliff, not far from Aurangabad, in Maharashtra. Ellora, with its uninterrupted sequence of monuments dating from A.D. 600 to 1000, brings the civilization of ancient India to life. Not only is the Ellora complex a unique artistic creation and a technological exploit but, with its sanctuaries devoted to Buddhism, Hinduism and Jainism, it illustrates the spirit of tolerance that was characteristic of ancient India.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Elephanta Caves,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The 'City of Caves', on an island in the Sea of Oman close to Bombay, contains a collection of rock art linked to the cult of Shiva. Here, Indian art has found one of its most perfect expressions, particularly the huge high reliefs in the main cave.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Sun Temple, Konârak,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column3: rak

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection
On the shores of the Bay of Bengal, bathed in the rays of the rising sun, the temple at Konarak is a monumental representation of the sun god Surya's chariot
column2: its 24 wheels are decorated with symbolic designs and it is led by a team of six horses. Built in the 13th century, it is one of India's most famous Brahman sanctuaries.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

This group of sanctuaries, founded by the Pallava kings, was carved out of rock along the Coromandel coast in the 7th and 8th centuries. It is known especially for its rathas (temples in the form of chariots), mandapas (cave sanctuaries), giant open-air reliefs such as the famous 'Descent of the Ganges', and the temple of Rivage, with thousands of sculptures to the glory of Shiva.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Djoudj National Bird Sanctuary,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Situated in the Senegal River delta, the Djoudj Sanctuary is a wetland of 16,000 ha, comprising a large lake surrounded by streams, ponds and backwaters. It forms a living but fragile sanctuary for some 1.5 million birds, such as the white pelican, the purple heron, the African spoonbill, the great egret and the cormorant.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Great Living Chola Temples,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The Great Living Chola Temples were built by kings of the Chola Empire, which stretched over all of south India and the neighbouring islands. The site includes three great 11th- and 12th-century Temples: the Brihadisvara Temple at Thanjavur, the Brihadisvara Temple at Gangaikondacholisvaram and the Airavatesvara Temple at Darasuram. The Temple of Gangaikondacholisvaram, built by Rajendra I, was completed in 1035. Its 53-m vimana (sanctum tower) has recessed corners and a graceful upward curving movement, contrasting with the straight and severe tower at Thanjavur. The Airavatesvara temple complex, built by Rajaraja II, at Darasuram features a 24-m vimana and a stone image of Shiva. The temples testify to the brilliant achievements of the Chola in architecture, sculpture, painting and bronze casting.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Agra Fort,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Walls of the Red Fort of Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India, UNESCO World Heritage Site
Murailles du Fort rouge de Agra, Uttar Pradesh, Inde, Site du Patrimoine Mondial de lï¿½UNESCO
Rote Mauern des Agra Forts, Uttar Pradesh, Indien, Welterbe der UNESCO

Near the gardens of the Taj Mahal stands the important 16th-century Mughal monument known as the Red Fort of Agra. This powerful fortress of red sandstone encompasses, within its 2.5-km-long enclosure walls, the imperial city of the Mughal rulers. It comprises many fairy-tale palaces, such as the Jahangir Palace and the Khas Mahal, built by Shah Jahan
column2: audience halls, such as the Diwan-i-Khas
column3: and two very beautiful mosques.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Taj Mahal,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

An immense mausoleum of white marble, built in Agra between 1631 and 1648 by order of the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his favourite wife, the Taj Mahal is the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Fatehpur Sikri,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Diwan-i-Khas, Hall of private Audience of the Emperor Akbar, Fatehpur Sikri, Uttar Pradesh, India, UNESCO World Heritage Site
Diwan-i-Khas, Hall des audiences privï¿½es de lï¿½Empereur Akbar, Fatehpur Sikri, Uttar Pradesh, Inde, Site du Patrimoine Mondial de lï¿½UNESCO
Diwan-i-Khas, Die private Audienzhalle, Fatehpur Sikri, Uttar Pradesh, Indien, Welterbe der UNESCO

Built during the second half of the 16th century by the Emperor Akbar, Fatehpur Sikri (the City of Victory) was the capital of the Mughal Empire for only some 10 years. The complex of monuments and temples, all in a uniform architectural style, includes one of the largest mosques in India, the Jama Masjid.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Wood Buffalo National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Situated on the plains in the north-central region of Canada, the park (which covers 44,807 km2) is home to North America's largest population of wild bison. It is also the natural nesting place of the whooping crane. Another of the park's attractions is the world's largest inland delta, located at the mouth of the Peace and Athabasca rivers.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Gulf of Porto: Calanche of Piana, Gulf of Girolata, Scandola Reserve,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Gulf of Porto: Calanche of Piana, Gulf of Girolata, Scandola Reserve

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The nature reserve, which is part of the Regional Natural Park of Corsica, occupies the Scandola peninsula, an impressive, porphyritic rock mass. The vegetation is an outstanding example of scrubland. Seagulls, cormorants and sea eagles can be found there. The clear waters, with their islets and inaccessible caves, host a rich marine life.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Great Smoky Mountains National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Stretching over more than 200,000 ha, this exceptionally beautiful park is home to more than 3,500 plant species, including almost as many trees (130 natural species) as in all of Europe. Many endangered animal species are also found there, including what is probably the greatest variety of salamanders in the world. Since the park is relatively untouched, it gives an idea of temperate flora before the influence of humankind.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column2: e,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column3: e

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection

column2: e lies off the coast of Senegal, opposite Dakar. From the 15th to the 19th century, it was the largest slave-trading centre on the African coast. Ruled in succession by the Portuguese, Dutch, English and French, its architecture is characterized by the contrast between the grim slave-quarters and the elegant houses of the slave traders. Today it continues to serve as a reminder of human exploitation and as a sanctuary for reconciliation.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Sangay National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Our Place The World Heritage Collection /
Our Place The World Heritage Collection

With its outstanding natural beauty and two active volcanoes, the park illustrates the entire spectrum of ecosystems, ranging from tropical rainforests to glaciers, with striking contrasts between the snowcapped peaks and the forests of the plains. Its isolation has encouraged the survival of indigenous species such as the mountain tapir and the Andean condor.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column2: e de Mai Nature Reserve,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column3: e de Mai Nature Reserve

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

In the heart of the small island of Praslin, the reserve has the vestiges of a natural palm forest preserved in almost its original state. The famous coco de mer, from a palm-tree once believed to grow in the depths of the sea, is the largest seed in the plant kingdom.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Monastery of the Hieronymites and Tower of Bel&#xe9
column2: m in Lisbon,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
color=""#3366cc""><strong>Monastery of the Hieronymites and Tower of Bel&#xe9
column3: m in Lisbon

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Monastery of the Hieronymites and Tower of Belï¿½m in Lisbon
Standing at the entrance to Lisbon harbour, the Monastery of the Hieronymites &ndash
column3: exemplifies Portuguese art at its best. The nearby Tower of Bel&eacute
column4: m, built to commemorate Vasco da Gama's expedition, is a reminder of the great maritime discoveries that laid the foundations of the modern world.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Monastery of Batalha,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The Monastery of the Dominicans of Batalha was built to commemorate the victory of the Portuguese over the Castilians at the battle of Aljubarrota in 1385. It was to be the Portuguese monarchy's main building project for the next two centuries. Here a highly original, national Gothic style evolved, profoundly influenced by Manueline art, as demonstrated by its masterpiece, the Royal Cloister.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Convent of Christ in Tomar,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Originally designed as a monument symbolizing the Reconquest, the Convent of the Knights Templar of Tomar (transferred in 1344 to the Knights of the Order of Christ) came to symbolize just the opposite during the Manueline period ï¿½ the opening up of Portugal to other civilizations.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: La Fortaleza and San Juan National Historic Site in Puerto Rico,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc""> La Fortaleza and San Juan National Historic Site in Puerto Rico

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
La Fortaleza and San Juan National Historic Site in Puerto Rico

Between the 15th and 19th centuries, a series of defensive structures was built at this strategic point in the Caribbean Sea to protect the city and the Bay of San Juan. They represent a fine display of European military architecture adapted to harbour sites on the American continent.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Old City of Berne,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection

Founded in the 12th century on a hill site surrounded by the Aare River, Berne developed over the centuries in line with a an exceptionally coherent planning concept. The buildings in the Old City, dating from a variety of periods, include 15th-century arcades and 16th-century fountains. Most of the medieval town was restored in the 18th century but it has retained its original character.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Convent of St Gall,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Convent of St. Gall (Deutsch: Fï¿½rstabtei St. Gallen)

The Convent of St Gall, a perfect example of a great Carolingian monastery, was, from the 8th century to its secularization in 1805, one of the most important in Europe. Its library is one of the richest and oldest in the world and contains precious manuscripts such as the earliest-known architectural plan drawn on parchment. From 1755 to 1768, the conventual area was rebuilt in Baroque style. The cathedral and the library are the main features of this remarkable architectural complex, reflecting 12 centuries of continuous activity.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Benedictine Convent of St John at M&#xfc
column2: stair,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
color=""#3366cc""><strong>Benedictine Convent of St John at M&#xfc
column3: stair

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
The Convent of Mï¿½stair, which stands in a valley in the Grisons, is a good example of Christian monastic renovation during the Carolingian period. It has Switzerland&#39
column2: s greatest series of figurative murals, painted c. A.D. 800, along with Romanesque frescoes and stuccoes.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Mesa Verde National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

A great concentration of ancestral Pueblo Indian dwellings, built from the 6th to the 12th century, can be found on the Mesa Verde plateau in south-west Colorado at an altitude of more than 2,600 m. Some 4,400 sites have been recorded, including villages built on the Mesa top. There are also imposing cliff dwellings, built of stone and comprising more than 100 rooms.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Pilgrimage Church of Wies,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Miraculously preserved in the beautiful setting of an Alpine valley, the Church of Wies (1745&ndash
column2: 54), the work of architect Dominikus Zimmermann, is a masterpiece of Bavarian Rococo &ndash
column3: exuberant, colourful and joyful.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column2: beck,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column3: beck

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

column3: the former capital and Queen City of the Hanseatic League &ndash
column4: was founded in the 12th century and prospered until the 16th century as the major trading centre for northern Europe. It has remained a centre for maritime commerce to this day, particularly with the Nordic countries. Despite the damage it suffered during the Second World War, the basic structure of the old city, consisting mainly of 15th- and 16th-century patrician residences, public monuments (the famous Holstentor brick gate), churches and salt storehouses, remains unaltered.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: City of Cuzco,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Situated in the Peruvian Andes, Cuzco developed, under the Inca ruler Pachacutec, into a complex urban centre with distinct religious and administrative functions. It was surrounded by clearly delineated areas for agricultural, artisan and industrial production. When the Spaniards conquered it in the 16th century, they preserved the basic structure but built Baroque churches and palaces over the ruins of the Inca city.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Historic Sanctuary of Machu Picchu,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Machu Picchu stands 2,430 m above sea-level, in the middle of a tropical mountain forest, in an extraordinarily beautiful setting. It was probably the most amazing urban creation of the Inca Empire at its height
column2: its giant walls, terraces and ramps seem as if they have been cut naturally in the continuous rock escarpments. The natural setting, on the eastern slopes of the Andes, encompasses the upper Amazon basin with its rich diversity of flora and fauna.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Jesuit Missions of the Guaranis: San Ignacio Mini, Santa Ana, Nuestra Señora de Loreto and Santa Maria Mayor (Argentina), Ruins of Sao Miguel das Missoes (Brazil),"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc""><strong>Jesuit Missions of the Guaranis: San Ignacio Mini, Santa Ana, Nuestra Se&#xf1
column3: ora de Loreto and Santa Maria Mayor (Argentina), Ruins of Sao Miguel das Missoes (Brazil)

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Jesuit Missions of the Guaranis: San Ignacio Mini, Santa Ana, Nuestra Seï¿½ora de Loreto and Santa Maria Mayor (Argentina), Ruins of Sao Miguel das Missoes (Brazil)

The ruins of Sï¿½o Miguel das Missï¿½es in Brazil, and those of San Ignacio Minï¿½, Santa Ana, Nuestra Seï¿½ora de Loreto and Santa Marï¿½a la Mayor in Argentina, lie at the heart of a tropical forest. They are the impressive remains of five Jesuit missions, built in the land of the Guaranis during the 17th and 18th centuries. Each is characterized by a specific layout and a different state of conservation.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Samarra Archaeological City,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Samarra Archaeological City is the site of a powerful Islamic capital city that ruled over the provinces of the Abbasid Empire extending from Tunisia to Central Asia for a century. Located on both sides of the River Tigris 130 km north of Baghdad, the length of the site from north to south is 41.5 km
column2: its width varying from 8 km to 4 km. It testifies to the architectural and artistic innovations that developed there and spread to the other regions of the Islamic world and beyond. The 9th-century Great Mosque and its spiral minaret are among the numerous remarkable architectural monuments of the site, 80% of which remain to be excavated.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Hatra,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

A large fortified city under the influence of the Parthian Empire and capital of the first Arab Kingdom, Hatra withstood invasions by the Romans in A.D. 116 and 198 thanks to its high, thick walls reinforced by towers. The remains of the city, especially the temples where Hellenistic and Roman architecture blend with Eastern decorative features, attest to the greatness of its civilization.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Yellowstone National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
The vast natural forest of Yellowstone National Park covers nearly 9,000 km2
column2: 96% of the park lies in Wyoming, 3% in Montana and 1% in Idaho. Yellowstone contains half of all the world's known geothermal features, with more than 10,000 examples. It also has the world's largest concentration of geysers (more than 300 geyers, or two thirds of all those on the planet). Established in 1872, Yellowstone is equally known for its wildlife, such as grizzly bears, wolves, bison and wapitis.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Salonga National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Salonga National Park is Africa's largest tropical rainforest reserve. Situated at the heart of the central basin of the Congo river, the park is very isolated and accessible only by water. It is the habitat of many endemic endangered species, such as the dwarf chimpanzee, the Congo peacock, the forest elephant and the African slender-snouted or 'false' crocodile.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Royal Chitwan National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Single-horned Asiatic rhinoceros, Royal Chitwan National Park
? ? u m i ï¿½ r e ? /
? ? u m i ï¿½ r e ?

At the foot of the Himalayas, Chitwan is one of the few remaining undisturbed vestiges of the 'Terai' region, which formerly extended over the foothills of India and Nepal. It has a particularly rich flora and fauna. One of the last populations of single-horned Asiatic rhinoceros lives in the park, which is also one of the last refuges of the Bengal tiger.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Port, Fortresses and Group of Monuments, Cartagena,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Port, Fortresses and Group of Monuments, Cartagena

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection

Situated in a bay in the Caribbean Sea, Cartagena has the most extensive fortifications in South America. A system of zones divides the city into three neighbourhoods: San Pedro, with the cathedral and many Andalusian-style palaces
column2: San Diego, where merchants and the middle class lived
column3: and Gethsemani, the 'popular quarter'.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Vatican City,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The Vatican City, one of the most sacred places in Christendom, attests to a great history and a formidable spiritual venture. A unique collection of artistic and architectural masterpieces lie within the boundaries of this small state. At its centre is St Peter's Basilica, with its double colonnade and a circular piazza in front and bordered by palaces and gardens. The basilica, erected over the tomb of St Peter the Apostle, is the largest religious building in the world, the fruit of the combined genius of Bramante, Raphael, Michelangelo, Bernini and Maderna.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Rock-Art Sites of Tadrart Acacus,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

On the borders of Tassili N'Ajjer in Algeria, also a World Heritage site, this rocky massif has thousands of cave paintings in very different styles, dating from 12,000 B.C. to A.D. 100. They reflect marked changes in the fauna and flora, and also the different ways of life of the populations that succeeded one another in this region of the Sahara.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Castles of Augustusburg and Falkenlust at Br&#xfc
column2: hl,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
color=""#3366cc""><strong>Castles of Augustusburg and Falkenlust at Br&#xfc
column3: hl

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
View of Augustusburg Palace and gardens from the South in morning light.
ï¿½ OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /

Set in an idyllic garden landscape, Augustusburg Castle (the sumptuous residence of the prince-archbishops of Cologne) and the Falkenlust hunting lodge (a small rural folly) are among the earliest examples of Rococo architecture in 18th-century Germany.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Lake Malawi National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Located at the southern end of the great expanse of Lake Malawi, with its deep, clear waters and mountain backdrop, the national park is home to many hundreds of fish species, nearly all endemic. Its importance for the study of evolution is comparable to that of the finches of the Galapagos Islands.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column2: s Historic Centre,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column3: s Historic Centre

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The historic centre of Cracow, the former capital of Poland, is situated at the foot of the Royal Wawel Castle. The 13th-century merchants' town has Europe's largest market square and numerous historical houses, palaces and churches with their magnificent interiors. Further evidence of the town's fascinating history is provided by the remnants of the 14th-century fortifications and the medieval site of Kazimierz with its ancient synagogues in the southern part of town, Jagellonian University and the Gothic cathedral where the kings of Poland were buried.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Cologne Cathedral,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Begun in 1248, the construction of this Gothic masterpiece took place in several stages and was not completed until 1880. Over seven centuries, successive builders were inspired by the same faith and a spirit of absolute fidelity to the original plans. Apart from its exceptional intrinsic value and the artistic masterpieces it contains, Cologne Cathedral testifies to the enduring strength of European Christianity.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Anjar,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The city of Anjar was founded by Caliph Walid I at the beginning of the 8th century. The ruins reveal a very regular layout, reminiscent of the palace-cities of ancient times, and are a unique testimony to city planning under the Umayyads.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Baalbek,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

This Phoenician city, where a triad of deities was worshipped, was known as Heliopolis during the Hellenistic period. It retained its religious function during Roman times, when the sanctuary of the Heliopolitan Jupiter attracted thousands of pilgrims. Baalbek, with its colossal structures, is one of the finest examples of Imperial Roman architecture at its apogee.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Byblos,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The ruins of many successive civilizations are found at Byblos, one of the oldest Phoenician cities. Inhabited since Neolithic times, it has been closely linked to the legends and history of the Mediterranean region for thousands of years. Byblos is also directly associated with the history and diffusion of the Phoenician alphabet.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Tyre,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

According to legend, purple dye was invented in Tyre. This great Phoenician city ruled the seas and founded prosperous colonies such as Cadiz and Carthage, but its historical role declined at the end of the Crusades. There are important archaeological remains, mainly from Roman times.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Aachen Cathedral,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Construction of this palatine chapel, with its octagonal basilica and cupola, began c. 790ï¿½800 under the Emperor Charlemagne. Originally inspired by the churches of the Eastern part of the Holy Roman Empire, it was splendidly enlarged in the Middle Ages.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Historic Centre of Warsaw,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection /
OUR PLACE The World Heritage Collection

During the Warsaw Uprising in August 1944, more than 85% of Warsaw's historic centre was destroyed by Nazi troops. After the war, a five-year reconstruction campaign by its citizens resulted in today's meticulous restoration of the Old Town, with its churches, palaces and market-place. It is an outstanding example of a near-total reconstruction of a span of history covering the 13th to the 20th century.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column3: bec. The Upper Town, built on the cliff, has remained the religious and administrative centre, with its churches, convents and other monuments like the Dauphine Redoubt, the Citadel and Ch&acirc
column4: teau Frontenac. Together with the Lower Town and its ancient districts, it forms an urban ensemble which is one of the best examples of a fortified colonial city.

column1: Mana Pools National Park, Sapi and Chewore Safari Areas,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Mana Pools National Park, Sapi and Chewore Safari Areas

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Parc national de Mana Pools, aires de safari Sapi et Chewore

On the banks of the Zambezi, great cliffs overhang the river and the floodplains. The area is home to a remarkable concentration of wild animals, including elephants, buffalo, leopards and cheetahs. An important concentration of Nile crocodiles is also be found in the area.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Iguazu National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The semicircular waterfall at the heart of this site is some 80 m high and 2,700 m in diameter and is situated on a basaltic line spanning the border between Argentina and Brazil. Made up of many cascades producing vast sprays of water, it is one of the most spectacular waterfalls in the world. The surrounding subtropical rainforest has over 2,000 species of vascular plants and is home to the typical wildlife of the region: tapirs, giant anteaters, howler monkeys, ocelots, jaguars and caymans.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The contiguous national parks of Banff, Jasper, Kootenay and Yoho, as well as the Mount Robson, Mount Assiniboine and Hamber provincial parks, studded with mountain peaks, glaciers, lakes, waterfalls, canyons and limestone caves, form a striking mountain landscape. The Burgess Shale fossil site, well known for its fossil remains of soft-bodied marine animals, is also found there.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Matobo Hills,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The area exhibits a profusion of distinctive rock landforms rising above the granite shield that covers much of Zimbabwe. The large boulders provide abundant natural shelters and have been associated with human occupation from the early Stone Age right through to early historical times, and intermittently since. They also feature an outstanding collection of rock paintings. The Matobo Hills continue to provide a strong focus for the local community, which still uses shrines and sacred places closely linked to traditional, social and economic activities.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Statue of Liberty,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Made in Paris by the French sculptor Bartholdi, in collaboration with Gustave Eiffel (who was responsible for the steel framework), this towering monument to liberty was a gift from France on the centenary of American independence in 1886. Standing at the entrance to New York Harbour, it has welcomed millions of immigrants to the United States ever since.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Yosemite National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Yosemite National Park lies in the heart of California. With its 'hanging' valleys, many waterfalls, cirque lakes, polished domes, moraines and U-shaped valleys, it provides an excellent overview of all kinds of granite relief fashioned by glaciation. At 600&ndash
column2: 4,000 m, a great variety of flora and fauna can also be found here.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Historic Centre of Salvador de Bahia,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Historic Centre of Salvador de Bahia

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Colonial mansions of Pelourinho in the historic center, Salvador, State of Bahia, Brazil, UNESCO World Heritage Site
Maisons coloniales du Pelourinho dans le centre historique, Salvador, Etat de Bahia, Brï¿½sil, Site du Patrimoine Mondial de lï¿½UNESCO
Kolonialhï¿½user, Kolonialhaeuser im historischen Zentrum von Pelourinho, Salvador, Staat Bahia, Brasilien, Welterbe der UNESCO

As the first capital of Brazil, from 1549 to 1763, Salvador de Bahia witnessed the blending of European, African and Amerindian cultures. It was also, from 1558, the first slave market in the New World, with slaves arriving to work on the sugar plantations. The city has managed to preserve many outstanding Renaissance buildings. A special feature of the old town are the brightly coloured houses, often decorated with fine stucco-work.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Auschwitz Birkenau German Nazi Concentration and Extermination Camp (1940-1945),"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Auschwitz Birkenau German Nazi Concentration and Extermination Camp (1940-1945)

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The fortified walls, barbed wire, platforms, barracks, gallows, gas chambers and cremation ovens show the conditions within which the Nazi genocide took place in the former concentration and extermination camp of Auschwitz-Birkenau, the largest in the Third Reich. According to historical investigations, 1.5 million people, among them a great number of Jews, were systematically starved, tortured and murdered in this camp, the symbol of humanity's cruelty to its fellow human beings in the 20th century.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain

Seventeen decorated caves of the Paleolithic age were inscribed as an extension to the Altamira Cave, inscribed in 1985. The property will now appear on the List as Cave of Altamira and Paleolithic Cave Art of Northern Spain. The property represents the apogee of Paleolithic cave art that developed across Europe, from the Urals to the Iberian Peninusula, from 35,000 to 11,000 BC. Because of their deep galleries, isolated from external climatic influences, these caves are particularly well preserved. The caves are inscribed as masterpieces of creative genius and as the humanity&rsquo
column2: s earliest accomplished art. They are also inscribed as exceptional testimonies to a cultural tradition and as outstanding illustrations of a significant stage in human history.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Old Town of Segovia and its Aqueduct,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Old Town of Segovia and its Aqueduct

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The Roman aqueduct of Segovia, probably built c. A.D. 50, is remarkably well preserved. This impressive construction, with its two tiers of arches, forms part of the setting of the magnificent historic city of Segovia. Other important monuments include the Alcï¿½zar, begun around the 11th century, and the 16th-century Gothic cathedral.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Monuments of Oviedo and the Kingdom of the Asturias,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Monuments of Oviedo and the Kingdom of the Asturias

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Monuments of Oviedo and the Kingdom of the Asturias

In the 9th century the flame of Christianity was kept alive in the Iberian peninsula in the tiny Kingdom of the Asturias. Here an innovative pre-Romanesque architectural style was created that was to play a significant role in the development of the religious architecture of the peninsula. Its highest achievements can be seen in the churches of Santa Marï¿½a del Naranco, San Miguel de Lillo, Santa Cristina de Lena, the Cï¿½mara Santa and San Juliï¿½n de los Prados, in and around the ancient capital city of Oviedo. Associated with them is the remarkable contemporary hydraulic engineering structure known as La Foncalada.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Historic Centre of Cordoba,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Cordoba's period of greatest glory began in the 8th century after the Moorish conquest, when some 300 mosques and innumerable palaces and public buildings were built to rival the splendours of Constantinople, Damascus and Baghdad. In the 13th century, under Ferdinand III, the Saint, Cordoba's Great Mosque was turned into a cathedral and new defensive structures, particularly the Alcï¿½zar de los Reyes Cristianos and the Torre Fortaleza de la Calahorra, were erected.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column3: n, Granada

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Rising above the modern lower town, the Alhambra and the Albaycí
column2: n, situated on two adjacent hills, form the medieval part of Granada. To the east of the Alhambra fortress and residence are the magnificent gardens of the Generalife, the former rural residence of the emirs who ruled this part of Spain in the 13th and 14th centuries. The residential district of the Albayc&iacute
column3: n is a rich repository of Moorish vernacular architecture, into which the traditional Andalusian architecture blends harmoniously.
1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Burgos Cathedral,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Our Lady of Burgos was begun in the 13th century at the same time as the great cathedrals of the Ile-de-France and was completed in the 15th and 16th centuries. The entire history of Gothic art is summed up in its superb architecture and its unique collection of works of art, including paintings, choir stalls, reredos, tombs and stained-glass windows.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Monastery and Site of the Escurial, Madrid,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Monastery and Site of the Escurial, Madrid

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Monastery and Site of the Escurial, Madrid

Built at the end of the 16th century on a plan in the form of a grill, the instrument of the martyrdom of St Lawrence, the Escurial Monastery stands in an exceptionally beautiful site in Castile. Its austere architecture, a break with previous styles, had a considerable influence on Spanish architecture for more than half a century. It was the retreat of a mystic king and became, in the last years of Philip II's reign, the centre of the greatest political power of the time.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Wieliczka Salt Mine,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

This deposit of rock salt in Wieliczka-Bochnia has been mined since the 13th century. Spread over nine levels, it has 300 km of galleries with works of art, altars, and statues sculpted in the salt, making a fascinating pilgrimage into the past of a major industrial undertaking.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Seven properties built by the architect Antoni Gaudï¿½ (1852ï¿½1926) in or near Barcelona testify to Gaudï¿½s exceptional creative contribution to the development of architecture and building technology in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. These monuments represent an eclectic, as well as a very personal, style which was given free reign in the design of gardens, sculpture and all decorative arts, as well as architecture. The seven buildings are: Casa Vicens

column1: Historic Mosque City of Bagerhat,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Situated in the suburbs of Bagerhat, at the meeting-point of the Ganges and Brahmaputra rivers, this ancient city, formerly known as Khalifatabad, was founded by the Turkish general Ulugh Khan Jahan in the 15th century. The city&rsquo
column2: s infrastructure reveals considerable technical skill and an exceptional number of mosques and early Islamic monuments, many built of brick, can be seen there.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Ruins of the Buddhist Vihara at Paharpur,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Ruins of the Buddhist Vihara at Paharpur

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Ruins of the Buddhist Vihara at Paharpur

Evidence of the rise of Mahayana Buddhism in Bengal from the 7th century onwards, Somapura Mahavira, or the Great Monastery, was a renowned intellectual centre until the 12th century. Its layout perfectly adapted to its religious function, this monastery-city represents a unique artistic achievement. With its simple, harmonious lines and its profusion of carved decoration, it influenced Buddhist architecture as far away as Cambodia.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Royal Palaces of Abomey,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

From 1625 to 1900, 12 kings succeeded one another at the head of the powerful Kingdom of Abomey. With the exception of King Akaba, who had his own separate enclosure, they all had their palaces built within the same cob-wall area, in keeping with previous palaces as regards the use of space and materials. The royal palaces of Abomey are a unique reminder of this vanished kingdom.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Petra,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Inhabited since prehistoric times, this Nabataean caravan-city, situated between the Red Sea and the Dead Sea, was an important crossroads between Arabia, Egypt and Syria-Phoenicia. Petra is half-built, half-carved into the rock, and is surrounded by mountains riddled with passages and gorges. It is one of the world's most famous archaeological sites, where ancient Eastern traditions blend with Hellenistic architecture.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Quseir Amra,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Built in the early 8th century, this exceptionally well-preserved desert castle was both a fortress with a garrison and a residence of the Umayyad caliphs. The most outstanding features of this small pleasure palace are the reception hall and the hammam, both richly decorated with figurative murals that reflect the secular art of the time.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Belovezhskaya Pushcha / Bia?owie?a Forest,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

Situated on the watershed of the Baltic Sea and the Black Sea, this immense forest range, consisting of evergreens and broad-leaved trees, is home to some remarkable animal life, including rare mammals such as the wolf, the lynx and the otter, as well as some 300 European Bison, a species which has been reintroduced into the park.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Chavin (Archaeological Site),"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

The archaeological site of Chavin gave its name to the culture that developed between 1500 and 300 B.C. in this high valley of the Peruvian Andes. This former place of worship is one of the earliest and best-known pre-Columbian sites. Its appearance is striking, with the complex of terraces and squares, surrounded by structures of dressed stone, and the mainly zoomorphic ornamentation.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">

column2: 72 by the Almoravids, Marrakesh remained a political, economic and cultural centre for a long period. Its influence was felt throughout the western Muslim world, from North Africa to Andalusia. It has several impressive monuments dating from that period: the Koutoubiya Mosque, the Kasbah, the battlements, monumental doors, gardens, etc. Later architectural jewels include the Bandi&acirc
column3: Palace, the Ben Youssef Madrasa, the Saadian Tombs, several great residences and Place Jamaâ
column4: El Fna, a veritable open-air theatre.

column1: Punic Town of Kerkuane and its Necropolis,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Punic Town of Kerkuane and its Necropolis

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Punic Town of Kerkuane and its Necropolis

This Phoenician city was probably abandoned during the First Punic War (c. 250 B.C.) and as a result was not rebuilt by the Romans. The remains constitute the only example of a Phoenicio-Punic city to have survived. The houses were built to a standard plan in accordance with a sophisticated notion of town planning.

column2: s highest tropical mountain range, Mount Huascarï¿½n rises to 6,768 m above sea-level. The deep ravines watered by numerous torrents, the glacial lakes and the variety of the vegetation make it a site of spectacular beauty. It is the home of such species as the spectacled bear and the Andean condor.

column2: an outdoor stairway decorated with statues of the prophets
column3: and seven chapels illustrating the Stations of the Cross, in which the polychrome sculptures by Aleijadinho are masterpieces of a highly original, moving, expressive form of Baroque art.

column1: Nanda Devi and Valley of Flowers National Parks,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">

column2: color=""#3366cc"">Nanda Devi and Valley of Flowers National Parks

column1: <table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Nanda Devi and Valley of Flowers National Parks

column2: s Valley of Flowers National Park is renowned for its meadows of endemic alpine flowers and outstanding natural beauty. This richly diverse area is also home to rare and endangered animals, including the Asiatic black bear, snow leopard, brown bear and blue sheep. The gentle landscape of the Valley of Flowers National Park complements the rugged mountain wilderness of Nanda Devi National Park. Together they encompass a unique transition zone between the mountain ranges of the Zanskar and Great Himalaya, praised by mountaineers and botanists for over a century and in Hindu mythology for much longer.

column3: 1992-2010 UNESCO World Heritage Centre, All Rights Reserved

column1: Kaziranga National Park,"<table width=""356"" cellpadding=""16"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" bgColor=""#ffffff"">
<table cellpadding=""5"" width=""356"" align=""center"" cellspacing=""0""><tr><td  bgColor=""#e8eff7"" align=""center"">
Wild Asian, Asiatic Elephants and Indian or Great One-horned Rhinoceros  in the swamp, Kaziranga national park, Assam, India,
Elephas maximus, Elephantidae family, Proboscidea Order,  Rhinoceros unicornis, Rhinocerotidae family, Perissodactyla Order
